# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

Here's the implementation of the `wrap_string` function:
```julia
function wrap_string(text)
    # Split text into words
    words = split(text, " ")

    # Initialize a new line character
    newline = "\n"

    # Iterate over each word and add a new line if necessary
    for i in 1:length(words)-1
        # Check if the current word plus any leading whitespace would exceed the maximum text width
        if length(words[i])) + length(words[i+1]]) > text_width
            # If the maximum text width has been exceeded, add a new line to wrap the current word and its leading whitespace
            newline = "\n"
            words[i+1]] += length(words[i+1]])) + length(words[i+1]]))]
```

And here's an example usage of the `wrap_string` function:
```julia
text_width = 5

# Wrap the given text into lines that are no longer than the maximum text width
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text)

println(wrapped_text)
```
